Award.AwardTitle: Conference Support for Karst, Groundwater Contamination & Public Health: Moving Beyond Case Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Karst terrains, which develop in carbonate rocks, limestone and dolomite, are common throughout the world and karst aquifers provide approximately 25% of world's drinking water. The characteristic cave, spring, and sinkhole features in karst terrains make karst aquifers highly vulnerable to contamination. Public health impacts stem from the ubiquity of karst terrains, the ease of introducing contaminants into the subsurface, and the pervasive use of karst aquifers to provide drinking water.

The proposed conference will bring together 80-100 scientists and regulators specializing in karst, groundwater contamination, and public health. The main goals are to bring together established and developing experts to elucidate current knowledge of karst and groundwater contamination, understand public health outcomes, and synthesize perspectives of the diverse disciplines into a new systematic framework for future research. While much is known separately about the physical hydrogeology of karst aquifers and the impact of contaminants on human health, there are significant knowledge gaps about contaminant transport and the direct human health consequences of contaminated karst waters. This will be the first meeting to be convened with the express focus of mutual exploration of research needs of these two scientific communities. The conference will expose young and under-represented scientific investigators to interdisciplinary study areas that offer great promise of useful knowledge for the future. Useful outcomes of the meeting will also include the translation of scientific knowledge from multiple sectors into information useful to public health and environmental regulators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MEETING LOGISTICS

The meeting was held at the Hilton Condado Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico between January 27th and 30th. A two-day field trip to the karst region of Puerto Rico took place on January 31st and February 1st.

ATTENDEES

There were 70 attendees at the meeting plus approximately 6 family members who attended some of the meeting events (mid-meeting field trip, banquet dinner, opening reception). The meeting attendees came from 7 countries: US, Denmark, Italy, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, and France. The US attendees came from Puerto Rico and 16 different states (Al, CO, DC, FL, IN, KY, MD, MI, MN, MO, NC, PA, PR, TN, TX, WI, WV). Attendees from Puerto Rico represented 4 universities (Univ. of PR Mayaguez, Univ. of PR Health Science Center, Univeridad del Turabo, Ponce Health Science University), 3 community groups (Citizens of the Karst, ENLACE del Cano Martin Pena, and the PR Speleological Society), and the Caribbean-Florida Water Science Center of the USGS. Government agencies represented included the Geologic Survey of Denmark and Greenland, National Research Council of Italy, Swiss Federal Office for the Environment, Edwards Aquifer Authority, US Environmental Protection Agency, National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS), and the US Geological Survey. Although approximately 65% of the attendees were geologists, there were also engineers, public health specialists, biologists, community representatives, a cave owner, and a lawyer. There were 45 professional attendees and 26 students.

TECHNICAL PROGRAM

There were 30 oral presentations, 20 posters and 12 short (5-minute) snap talks. On Saturday there were two afternoon field trips organized and lead by Excursions Eco http://www.excursioneseco.com/. Before going on these trips the group watched a film about the issues related to Cano Martin Pena and how the communities have responded to contamination in the San Juan Bay Estuary (the film can be watched at this URL: http://www.epa.gov/urbanwaterspartners/cano-martin-pena-martin-pena-channel-puerto-rico ). On Saturday evening there was banquet when the 2016 KWI award was given to Abel Vale of Citizens of the Karst (Ciudadanos Del Karso).

FIELD TRIP

A total of 37 people (including two children) attended the two day field trip after the meeting. The trip included stops at two commercial caves (Cueva Rio Camuy and Cueva Ventana), a former commercial Cave (Cueva Luz) and one wild cave. Additional stops visited sinkholes, springs, sinking valleys, and at overlooks.

FINANCIAL SUPPORT

The meeting was supported by three grants; proposals were written by the organizing committee. These provided some field trip support and a significant amount of attendee support. In addition to the NIEHS grant, additional funds were obtained from the National Science Foundation EAR division and the Edwards Aquifer Authority, San Antonio TX.

PUBLICATIONS

White, W., Herman, E., Rutigliano, M., Herman, J., Vesper, D., and Engel, S., Eds. (2016) Karst Groundwater Contamination and Public Health. Selected papers and abstracts of the symposium held January 27 through 30, 2016, San Juan, Puerto Rico. Karst Waters Institute Special Publication 19, Karst Waters Institute, Leesburg, Virginia, 74 p. ISBN 978-0-9789976-8-7. http://karstwaters.org/sp19- karst-groundwater-contamination-and-public-health/

Herman, J. S., Vesper, D. J., and Herman, E. K. (2016) Groundwater Contamination in Karst Regions Affects Human Health. Meeting Report. EOS. Online July 20, 2016; In print September 1, 2016. https://eos.org/meeting-reports/groundwater-contamination-in-karstregions-affects-human-health

White, W. B., Herman, J. S., Herman, E. K., and Rutigliano, M., Eds. (in press for 2017) Karst Groundwater Contamination & Public Health. Beyond Case Studies. The book currently had 40 submissions and is expected to be available in print in 2017.
